etymologies: Middle English: originally as noun in sense ‘thin, fluid mud’, later as verb meaning ‘smear, smirch’, ‘disparage (a person)’, ‘gloss over (a fault)’

definitions: speak (words or speech) indistinctly so that the sounds run into one another

examples.text: he was slurring his words like a drunk

shortDefinitions: speak words indistinctly so that sounds run into one another

definitions: (of words or speech) be spoken so the sounds run into one another

examples.text: his speech was beginning to slur

definitions: pass over (a fact or aspect) so as to conceal or minimize it

examples.text: essential attributes are being slurred over or ignored

shortDefinitions: pass over fact or aspect so as

definitions: perform (a group of two or more notes) legato

examples.text: I can play it if I don't slur the notes

definitions: make damaging or insulting insinuations or allegations about

examples.text: I was not trying to slur the integrity of the committee

shortDefinitions: make damaging or insulting insinuations or allegations about

definitions: an insinuation or allegation about someone that is likely to insult them or damage their reputation

examples.text: the comments were a slur on the staff

shortDefinitions: insinuation or allegation about someone that is likely to insult them or damage their reputation

definitions: a derogatory or insulting term applied to particular group of people
shortDefinitions: derogatory word applied to particular group

definitions: an act of speaking indistinctly so that sounds or words run into one another or a tendency to speak in such a way

examples.text: there was a mean slur in his voice

shortDefinitions: act of speaking indistinctly so that sounds or words run into one another

definitions: a curved line used to show that a group of two or more notes is to be sung to one syllable or played or sung legato.
shortDefinitions: curved line used to show that group of notes are to be sung to one syllable
